source.raw_text:
A "Quad Raise" (often the Quadruped Leg Raise) primarily targets core/abs, glutes, and hamstrings for stabilization, while the Leg Extension (or seated leg raise) directly works the quadriceps (Rectus Femoris, Vastus Medialis/Lateralis/Intermedius) to extend the knee, with the movement pattern being knee extension, essential for jumping, squatting, and walking. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Muscles Worked 
For the Quadruped Leg Raise (Stabilization) 

• Core: Rectus Abdominis, Obliques, Transverse Abdominis (deep core). 
• Glutes: Gluteus Maximus, Medius, Minimus (for hip stability). 
• Hamstrings: (Synergistically) for stabilizing the knee and hip. [1, 3, 5, 6, 7]  

For the Leg Extension (Direct Quad Work) 

• Rectus Femoris: Extends knee, flexes hip. 
• Vastus Medialis: Extends knee, stabilizes kneecap (teardrop muscle). 
• Vastus Lateralis: Extends knee, creates quad sweep. 
• Vastus Intermedius: Deepest quad muscle, extends knee. [3, 4, 5, 7, 8]  

Movement Patterns 

• Quadruped Leg Raise: A stabilization pattern focusing on anti-rotation and maintaining a neutral spine while extending one arm and opposite leg, working core endurance and hip/glute control. 
• Leg Extension: A classic knee extension pattern, involving straightening the leg at the knee joint (like kicking or standing up) and hip flexion (lifting the thigh) for the rectus femoris. [1, 2, 3, 4, 6]  

Key Difference 

• Quadruped Raise: A core/stability exercise that indirectly involves the quads for stabilization. 
• Leg Extension: A direct quad isolation exercise focused on building strength and size in the front thigh muscles. [1, 3, 6, 9]  

**Citations:**

[1] https://www.muscleandfitness.com/exercise/workouts/abs-and-core-exercises/quadruped-leg-raise/
